paper_title.en: Fate of food nitrogen in marine copepods

description.en: The stable isotope of nitrogen, N-15, was used to evaluate the nitrogen accumulation efficiency of copepods feeding on natural plankton assemblages from coastal waters over the period March to November 1998. Although allowances have to be made for selective feeding, the clearance rates calculated from the accumulation of N-15 were considerably lower than the rate of removal of the particles labeled with N-15. The percentage of accumulation/removal varied from 9 to 75 %. In 3 out of 5 experiments, the copepods released dissolved nitrogen from their food rather than accumulating it. It appears that, at least on some occasions, copepods may transfer much of the particulate organic nitrogen to the dissolved form, and thus short-circuit the food chain from phytoplankton to carnivores.

paper_title.en: Dissolved organic nitrogen dynamics in coastal waters and the effect of copepods

description.en: The dynamics of freshly released and N-15 labeled dissolved organic nitrogen ((DON)-N-15) in the < 94 mu m planktonic assemblages of coastal waters and the effects of herbivorous copepods on those dynamics were assessed by applying (NH4+)-N-15 under laboratory conditions. At the same time, the rate of NH4+ uptake and regeneration in the < 94 mu m planktonic assemblages, and the rates of ingestion and NH: regeneration by copepods were evaluated by N-15 accumulation in the particulate organic nitrogen (PON) fraction and in the copepods, and N-15(4)+ isotope dilution during the incubation. Under conditions of high ambient Chlorophyll a, the presence of copepods stimulated total community (DON)-N-15 release which was correlated with high ingestion rates of the copepods. The copepods primarily grazed on N-15 tagged phytoplankton and 'sloppy feeding' would be a mechanism responsible for the (DON)-N-15 release. On the other hand, the addition of copepods gave a negative effect on (DON)-N-15 release in <94 mu m plankton assemblages at the occasions when ambient Chlorophyll a concentrations were low and nitrogen-Chlorophyll a ratios were high. The micrograzer and other organic particles that less labeled by N-15 tracer, would be the important foods for the copepods under those conditions, while the possible (DON)-N-15 release by the micrograzer would be repressed by copepods grazing. When a stimulating effect of the copepods addition on relative (DON)-N-15 accumulation was found, the copepods sometimes released more N-15 labeled DON than 15N assimilated into their body. Even under those conditions, the rates of (DON)-N-15 release by copepods normalized to ambient zooplankton biomass are rather minor compared to those by planktonic assemblages of <94 mu m, suggesting the importance of microzooplankton and phytoplankton on (DON)-N-15 release in this coastal waters. (C) 2000 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

Release of dissolved organic nitrogen by size-fractionated natural planktonic assemblages in coastal waters

description.en: To evaluate the effect of differences in community structure on the process of dissolved organic nitrogen (DON) release in natural planktonic assemblages, (DON)-N-15 release from size-fractionated (<20 and <94 pm) waters of Akkeshi Bay, eastern Hokkaido, Japan, was measured after the addition of (NH4+)-N-15. Calculations of percent extracellular release (PER) based on particulate organic N-15-nitrogen ((PON)-N-15) and (DON)-N-15 accumulation were higher in the <20 mu m fraction than in the < 94 mu m fractions in 2 out of 3 experiments; though the absolute magnitude of the release was higher in the larger size-fraction. Phytoplankton was primarily responsible for the (DON)-N-15 release in the <20 pm fraction, which suggested more efficient DON release by smaller phytoplankton compared to larger ones. A passive permeation through the cell membrane is a likely explanation for the DON release observed in our study. PER (194 pm) fell within the range of 2.7 to 4.9%, which is almost equal to, or somewhat lower than, the PER reported for carbon. In addition, the occurrence of tight coupling between DON release and its consumption by bacteria was suggested in a time-course experiment. showing efficient use of released nitrogenous compounds within the natural community.

Predator-mediated coexistence of epiphytic grass shrimps that compete for refuges

description.en: Epiphytic grass shrimps, Latreutes acicularis and Heptacarpus geniculatus, are often found to coexist in seagrass beds in Japanese shallow seas. The seagrass provides effective refuges by its complex vegetation. A laboratory experiment showed that the competitive interactions between the two shrimps were qualitatively altered in the presence of a predator. H. geniculatus was competitively superior in the absence of the predator, while the presence of the predator acted to lower activities of both species, resulting in a reduced intra- and interspecific interference competition. Based on the experimental data on the behavioral changes, we constructed a model for population dynamics of the shrimp community, and examined the conditions for coexistence of the prey species in terms of their recruitment rates and death rates in the presence and absence of predator. The results show that predator-induced behavioral changes in competitive ability make coexistence significantly easier to achieve.
